title: China aids lab establishment in Polytechnic University of Tirana in Albania
description: On April 19 2016, Tirana University of Technology held the inauguration ceremony of the Geodetic Laboratory of the Department of Architectural Engineering and the Architectural Design Laboratory of the Department of Architecture and Urban Planning. The project was funded by a Chinese grant, although the commitment year remains unknown. Jiang Yu and Ambassador to Albania Tirana Polytechnic University Yueer Ka Qi attended the ceremony. Ambassador Jiang emphasized that the completion of the laboratory is a gratifying result of China-Albanian science and technology education cooperation.
staff_comments: The specific grant amount for the project remains unknown. Commitment year is uncertain as only completion date was captured.
combined_text:
# Sector
EDUCATION

# Title
China aids lab establishment in Polytechnic University of Tirana in Albania

# Description
On April 19 2016, Tirana University of Technology held the inauguration ceremony of the Geodetic Laboratory of the Department of Architectural Engineering and the Architectural Design Laboratory of the Department of Architecture and Urban Planning. The project was funded by a Chinese grant, although the commitment year remains unknown. Jiang Yu and Ambassador to Albania Tirana Polytechnic University Yueer Ka Qi attended the ceremony. Ambassador Jiang emphasized that the completion of the laboratory is a gratifying result of China-Albanian science and technology education cooperation.
justification: Project focuses on educational infrastructure development without direct environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Establishment of geodetic and architectural design laboratories at university, funded by Chinese grant

title: Chinese Government provides EUR 131,652 grant for Educational Equipment for Albanian Schools Project
description: According to official data that Albania’s Donor Technical Secretariat shared with AidData in February 2018, the Chinese Government provided a EUR 131,652 grant to the Government of Albania in 2016 for the Educational Equipment for Albanian Schools Project. This project involved the provision of educational equipment and teaching materials to 5 primary and secondary schools offering Chinese language courses in Albania. It commenced on June 6, 2016, and reached completion on September 9, 2016.
combined_text:
# Sector
EDUCATION

# Title
Chinese Government provides EUR 131,652 grant for Educational Equipment for Albanian Schools Project

# Description
According to official data that Albania’s Donor Technical Secretariat shared with AidData in February 2018, the Chinese Government provided a EUR 131,652 grant to the Government of Albania in 2016 for the Educational Equipment for Albanian Schools Project. This project involved the provision of educational equipment and teaching materials to 5 primary and secondary schools offering Chinese language courses in Albania. It commenced on June 6, 2016, and reached completion on September 9, 2016.
justification: Project focuses on educational equipment and materials without direct environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Provision of educational equipment and teaching materials to schools, no energy or environmental components mentioned

title: Chinese Government provides RMB 10 million grant for National Theatre of Opera, Ballet, and Folkloric Ensemble Reconstruction Project (Linked to Project ID#66132)
description: In 2016, the Chinese Government issued an RMB 10 million (EUR 1,843,137) to the Government of Albania for the provision of equipment to rehabilitate the National Theatre of Opera and Ballet and Folkloric Ensemble (Teatri Kombëtar i Operas dhe Baletit) in the capital city of Tirana. According to official data that Albania’s Donor Technical Secretariat shared with AidData in February 2018, the project commenced on April 15, 2016, and reached completion on December 30, 2018.  The recipient of the grant was the Albanian Ministry of Culture.
staff_comments: Project ID#66132 is also associated with the rehabilitation of the National Theatre of Opera and Ballet and Folkloric Ensemble.
combined_text:
# Sector
OTHER SOCIAL INFRASTRUCTURE AND SERVICES

# Title
Chinese Government provides RMB 10 million grant for National Theatre of Opera, Ballet, and Folkloric Ensemble Reconstruction Project (Linked to Project ID#66132)

# Description
In 2016, the Chinese Government issued an RMB 10 million (EUR 1,843,137) to the Government of Albania for the provision of equipment to rehabilitate the National Theatre of Opera and Ballet and Folkloric Ensemble (Teatri Kombëtar i Operas dhe Baletit) in the capital city of Tirana. According to official data that Albania’s Donor Technical Secretariat shared with AidData in February 2018, the project commenced on April 15, 2016, and reached completion on December 30, 2018.  The recipient of the grant was the Albanian Ministry of Culture.
justification: Project focuses on cultural infrastructure rehabilitation with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Rehabilitation of National Theatre of Opera and Ballet, cultural facility equipment provision

title: Chinese Government provides RMB 100 million grant — via ETCA — for Youth Culture and Leisure Complex Construction Project (Linked to Project ID#61201)
description: Between October 26, 2015 and November 15, 2015, Hunan Provincial Architectural Design Institute undertook a feasibility study for the Youth Culture and Leisure Complex Construction Project (with support from China’s Ministry of Commerce). Then, on June 2, 2016, the Chinese Government and the Government of Algeria signed an Economic and Technical Cooperation Agreement (ETCA), which committed RMB 100 million of grant funding for the Youth Culture and Leisure Complex Construction Project (captured in Project ID#52453). The agreement was signed by Yang Guangyu, Ambassador of China to Algeria, and the Algerian Secretary-General of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs.   On December 3, 2017, the Chinese Government and the Government of Algeria signed another Economic and Technical Cooperation Agreement (ETCA), which committed an additional RMB 200 million of grant funding for the Youth Culture and Leisure Complex Construction Project (captured in Project ID#61201).   The purpose of this project was to build a Youth Culture and Leisure Complex in the town of Diar El Baraka within the commune of Baraki. The complex will occupy 28,300 square meters and include a theater with 450 seats, 3 theaters with 50 seats, 2 sculpture rooms, 2 painting rooms, 3 rooms for language teaching, a multipurpose sports palace, a 50 meters swimming pool, two 25 meter swimming pools, a water basin for children, a youth hostel with 50 beds, several outdoor football pitches, administrative offices, and auxiliary equipment rooms.   Sinomach is the contractor responsible for project implementation. The funder of the project (MOFCOM) conducted a project site visit on May 9, 2018. Then, a project implementation agreement was signed on December 4, 2018. In September 2019, a geotechnical engineering survey was undertaken at the project site. It does not appear that construction has commenced.
staff_comments: This project is also known as the Algeria Youth Cultural Palace project. The French project title is Palais culturel et de loisirs or Palais culturel et de loisirs pour les jeunes. The Chinese project title is 阿尔及利亚青年文化宫项目 or 中国援阿尔及利亚青年文化宫项目.
combined_text:
# Sector
OTHER SOCIAL INFRASTRUCTURE AND SERVICES

# Title
Chinese Government provides RMB 100 million grant — via ETCA — for Youth Culture and Leisure Complex Construction Project (Linked to Project ID#61201)

# Description
Between October 26, 2015 and November 15, 2015, Hunan Provincial Architectural Design Institute undertook a feasibility study for the Youth Culture and Leisure Complex Construction Project (with support from China’s Ministry of Commerce). Then, on June 2, 2016, the Chinese Government and the Government of Algeria signed an Economic and Technical Cooperation Agreement (ETCA), which committed RMB 100 million of grant funding for the Youth Culture and Leisure Complex Construction Project (captured in Project ID#52453). The agreement was signed by Yang Guangyu, Ambassador of China to Algeria, and the Algerian Secretary-General of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs.   On December 3, 2017, the Chinese Government and the Government of Algeria signed another Economic and Technical Cooperation Agreement (ETCA), which committed an additional RMB 200 million of grant funding for the Youth Culture and Leisure Complex Construction Project (captured in Project ID#61201).   The purpose of this project was to build a Youth Culture and Leisure Complex in the town of Diar El Baraka within the commune of Baraki. The complex will occupy 28,300 square meters and include a theater with 450 seats, 3 theaters with 50 seats, 2 sculpture rooms, 2 painting rooms, 3 rooms for language teaching, a multipurpose sports palace, a 50 meters swimming pool, two 25 meter swimming pools, a water basin for children, a youth hostel with 50 beds, several outdoor football pitches, administrative offices, and auxiliary equipment rooms.   Sinomach is the contractor responsible for project implementation. The funder of the project (MOFCOM) conducted a project site visit on May 9, 2018. Then, a project implementation agreement was signed on December 4, 2018. In September 2019, a geotechnical engineering survey was undertaken at the project site. It does not appear that construction has commenced.
justification: Project focuses on cultural and leisure facilities without clear environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Youth Culture and Leisure Complex with theaters, sports facilities, and educational spaces

title: Chinese Embassy donates 50 sacrificial animals to needy families in Beni Milek
description: In 2016, the Chinese embassy distributed 50 sacrificial animals to Algerian families for the occasion of Eid El Adha. The animals were distributed to the mountainous town of Beni Milek by the President of the Algerian Red Crescent (ARC). This was stated to have benefitted 110 families. For the same occasion, the charity Errahma donated 30 sheep to needy families in the city of Tipasa.
combined_text:
# Sector
DEVELOPMENTAL FOOD AID/FOOD SECURITY ASSISTANCE

# Title
Chinese Embassy donates 50 sacrificial animals to needy families in Beni Milek

# Description
In 2016, the Chinese embassy distributed 50 sacrificial animals to Algerian families for the occasion of Eid El Adha. The animals were distributed to the mountainous town of Beni Milek by the President of the Algerian Red Crescent (ARC). This was stated to have benefitted 110 families. For the same occasion, the charity Errahma donated 30 sheep to needy families in the city of Tipasa.
justification: Project is focused on social welfare and food security without direct environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Distribution of sacrificial animals to needy families, humanitarian aid focus

title: Chinese Government provides RMB 16.03 million grant — via ETCA — for Phase 2 of Saline Farmland Improvement Project
description: On September 15, 2016, the Chinese Ambassador to Algeria and Secretary General of the Algerian Ministry of Agriculture, Rural Development, and Fisheries signed an RMB 16.03 million grant agreement for Phase 2 of Saline Farmland Improvement Project on behalf of their respective governments. The grant proceeds for this project were drawn from an Economic and Technical Cooperation Agreement (ETCA) that the two governments signed on June 26, 2013.   The purpose of this project was to dispatch seven Chinese agricultural experts over a three year period to (a) the central laboratory of the National Institute of Agronomic Research of Algeria (Institut National de la Recherche Agronomique d'Algérie or INRA or المعهد الوطني الجزائري للبحث الزراعي) in the capital city of Algiers, and (b) an INRAA experimental station in the town of Hmadna (El Hamadna or الحمادنة) within the wilaya of Relizane. It also involved the dispatching of eighteen experts and technicians for short-term visits to Algeria to advise and assist on issued related to saline farmland improvement.   Shanxi International Economic & Technical Cooperative Co Ltd. is the contractor responsible for implementation.A project implementation agreement was signed on May 9, 2018.  Project implementation subsequently commenced in July 2018 and it was expected to last until July 2021.  The Chinese Government also funded Phase 1 of this project (captured in Project ID#31785).
staff_comments: The French project title is l'amélioration des terres agricoles salines en Algérie or la deuxième phase du projet portant sur « l'amélioration des terres agricoles salines en Algérie ». The Chinese project title is 援阿尔及利亚土壤改良二期技术合作项目.
combined_text:
# Sector
AGRICULTURE, FORESTRY, FISHING

# Title
Chinese Government provides RMB 16.03 million grant — via ETCA — for Phase 2 of Saline Farmland Improvement Project

# Description
On September 15, 2016, the Chinese Ambassador to Algeria and Secretary General of the Algerian Ministry of Agriculture, Rural Development, and Fisheries signed an RMB 16.03 million grant agreement for Phase 2 of Saline Farmland Improvement Project on behalf of their respective governments. The grant proceeds for this project were drawn from an Economic and Technical Cooperation Agreement (ETCA) that the two governments signed on June 26, 2013.   The purpose of this project was to dispatch seven Chinese agricultural experts over a three year period to (a) the central laboratory of the National Institute of Agronomic Research of Algeria (Institut National de la Recherche Agronomique d'Algérie or INRA or المعهد الوطني الجزائري للبحث الزراعي) in the capital city of Algiers, and (b) an INRAA experimental station in the town of Hmadna (El Hamadna or الحمادنة) within the wilaya of Relizane. It also involved the dispatching of eighteen experts and technicians for short-term visits to Algeria to advise and assist on issued related to saline farmland improvement.   Shanxi International Economic & Technical Cooperative Co Ltd. is the contractor responsible for implementation.A project implementation agreement was signed on May 9, 2018.  Project implementation subsequently commenced in July 2018 and it was expected to last until July 2021.  The Chinese Government also funded Phase 1 of this project (captured in Project ID#31785).
justification: Project focuses on agricultural improvement and knowledge transfer without clear environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Saline farmland improvement, dispatch of agricultural experts, focus on agricultural research and development

title: CDB provides $10 billion to Government of Angola to recapitalize Sonangol and prepay outstanding debts (Linked to Project ID#66847, #87051, 95415)
description: On December 9, 2015, China Development Bank (CDB) entered into a $15 billion loan agreement (captured via Project ID#66847) with the Government of Angola. The loan is an oil prepayment facility with repayments being serviced through receivables from a designated oil contract. The pricing structure of the loan allows the Government of Angola to benefit from an upside in an increase in the price of oil. The loan has a maturity of 12 years and its availability period expired on December 9, 2017.    As a condition of the loan agreement, the lender required the borrower to maintain a minimum cash balance of approximately $1.5 billion in an escrow account known as the Debt Service Reserve Account (DSRA). The proceeds of the loan facility were used to be used to recapitalize Sonangol, help Sonangol prepay some of its outstanding debts to CDB, and finance a series of public investment projects. As of December 31, 2017, the loan had achieved a 100% disbursement rate. Repayments commenced in 2018. The loan’s amount outstanding was $14.9 billion in December 2018, $14.5 billion as of June 30, 2019, and $11.3 billion as of December 31, 2021.    In 2016, China Development Bank approved a $10 billion subsidiary loan through this facility (captured via Project ID#53063) to enable the Government of Angola to recapitalize Sonangol — Angola’s state-owned oil company — and help Sonangol prepay some of its outstanding debts to CDB. Sonangol had previously borrowed $7.5 billion from CDB between 2010 and 2014, and through an on-lending arrangement with the Government of Angola, Sonangol used $6.9 billion of the proceeds of the $10 billion loan to prepay several outstanding debts to CDB, including a $2.5 billion loan in 2010 for the Phase 1 of Kilamba Kiaxi Housing Construction Project (captured via Project ID#47101), a $2 billion loan in 2011 to support Sonangol’s development efforts (captured via Project ID#47102), and a $1 billion loan in 2012 to support Sonangol’s development efforts (captured via Project ID#47103).     According to the IMF, the $6.9 billion that was on-lent to Sonangol (as part of the $10 billion subsidiary loan) had a net value of $3.8 billion because part of it was used to refinance existing debt, implying that only $3.1 billion was used for re-financing. According to the IMF, after this recapitalization, Sonangol ‘significantly reduced its external debt, which [was] projected to decline to about US$5 billion at end-2018, from US$12.9 billion at end-2015.’ Therefore, rather than having the country’s state-owned oil company struggle to pay back CDB loans that were coming due, the Government of Angola effectively moved Sonangol’s CDB debts onto its own balance sheet.  There are clear indications that the December 2015 CDB loan financially underperformed vis-a-vis the original expectations of the lender. In December 2020, CDB and the Government of Angola entered into an agreement to reprofile multiple loan agreements that they had previously signed, including the $15 billion loan agreement from December 2015 (as captured via Project ID#95415). The December 2020 agreement included (i) a three-year deferral of principal payments; and (ii) repayment of deferred principal falling due in 2020H2–2023H1 over seven years after the grace period, with some additional modest relief of principal in 2024–25.   The Government of Angola also agreed to use the outstanding cash balance in an escrow account — known as the Debt Service Reserve Account (DSRA) — to make interest payments to the CDB between 2020 to 2022, which it expected would bring the DSRA balance to nearly zero by mid-2022. However, under the terms of the debt reprofiling agreement, the parties agreed that the borrower would need to replenish the DSRA to approximately $1.5 billion (the minimum cash balance previously agreed upon by the lender and borrower) by 2023.
staff_comments: 1. There is a discrepancy in the reported value of on-lending to Sonangol between two official sources: the IMF 2017 Article IV Staff Report and the Government of Angola’s November 2019 bond prospectus. The former suggests that the central government on-lent $6.9 million and the latter suggests that the central government on-lent $10 billion. For the time being, AidData relies on the Government of Angola’s November 2019 bond prospectus for the total amount on-lent to Sonangol and relies on the IMF’s 2017 Article IV Staff Report for the breakdown of the $10 billion. AidData assumes for the time being that the Government of Angola on-lent $10 billion to Sonangol, of which $3.1 billion was used to refinance Sonangol’s existing CDB debts. Therefore, AidData has coded the transaction (financial commitment) amount as $6.9 billion to avoid double-counting CDB loans that Sonangol previously contracted. 2. In the Chinese Loans to Africa (CLA) Database that SAIS-CARI released in July 2020 and updated in March 2021 (which is now maintained by Boston University’s Global Development Policy Center), a $10 billion loan from CDB to the Government of Angola is recorded to captured the recapitalization of Sonangol. The CLA database does not expunge the portion of the loan ($3.1 billion) that was used to refinance Sonangol’s existing CDB debts. 3. AidData Project ID#87051 captures the portion of the loan used for re-financing, though no transaction amount has been recorded.  4. Oil prepayment contracts are also known as pre-export finance (PXF) facilities. A PXF facility is an arrangement in which a commodity (e.g. oil) producer gets up-front cash from a customer in return for a promise to repay the customer with that commodity (possibly at a discount) in the future. PXF funds may be advanced by a lender or syndicate of lenders to a commodity producer to assist the company in meeting either its working capital needs (for example, to cover the purchase of raw materials and costs associated with processing, storage and transport) or its capital investment needs (for example, investment in plant and machinery and other elements of infrastructure). PXF facilities are usually secured by (1) an assignment of rights by the producer under an ‘offtake contract’ (i.e., a sale and purchase contract between the producer and a buyer of that producer of goods or commodities), and (2) a collection account charge over a bank account into which proceeds due to the producer from the buyer of the goods or commodities under the offtake contract are credited. There are two key documents in prepayment finance transactions: a contract providing for the advance payment by the offtaker to the producer for the purchase of goods/commodities (the 'Prepayment Contract'), and a loan agreement between a lender and the offtaker (the 'Offtaker Loan Agreement') under which the advance payment is financed.5. The interest rate and grace period that apply to the December 9, 2015 loan are unknown. For the time being, AidData relies on the weighted average interest rate (4.334%) and weighted average grace period (3.8333) that the World Bank's Debtor Reporting System (DRS) identifies as applying to China's official sector lending to Angola in 2015. See https://www.dropbox.com/s/949n5rctiue6d7c/IDS_Average_grace_period_and_maturity_on_new_external_debt_commitments.xlsx?dl=0 and https://www.dropbox.com/s/ab8qt4n6jijcbhd/IDS_Average%20interest%20on%20new%20external%20debt%20commitments.xlsx?dl=0
combined_text:
# Sector
ENERGY

# Title
CDB provides $10 billion to Government of Angola to recapitalize Sonangol and prepay outstanding debts (Linked to Project ID#66847, #87051, 95415)

# Description
On December 9, 2015, China Development Bank (CDB) entered into a $15 billion loan agreement (captured via Project ID#66847) with the Government of Angola. The loan is an oil prepayment facility with repayments being serviced through receivables from a designated oil contract. The pricing structure of the loan allows the Government of Angola to benefit from an upside in an increase in the price of oil. The loan has a maturity of 12 years and its availability period expired on December 9, 2017. The loan’s amount outstanding was $14.9 billion in December 2018, $14.5 billion as of June 30, 2019, and $11.3 billion as of December 31, 2021.    In 2016, China Development Bank approved a $10 billion subsidiary loan through this facility (captured via Project ID#53063) to enable the Government of Angola to recapitalize Sonangol — Angola’s state-owned oil company — and help Sonangol prepay some of its outstanding debts to CDB. According to the IMF, the $6.9 billion that was on-lent to Sonangol (as part of the $10 billion subsidiary loan) had a net value of $3.8 billion because part of it was used to refinance existing debt, implying that only $3.1 billion was used for re-financing. According to the IMF, after this recapitalization, Sonangol ‘significantly reduced its external debt, which [was] projected to decline to about US$5 billion at end-2018, from US$12.9 billion at end-2015.’ Therefore, rather than having the country’s state-owned oil company struggle to pay back CDB loans that were coming due, the Government of Angola effectively moved Sonangol’s CDB debts onto its own balance sheet.  There are clear indications that the December 2015 CDB loan financially underperformed vis-a-vis the original expectations of the lender. In December 2020, CDB and the Government of Angola entered into an agreement to reprofile multiple loan agreements that they had previously signed, including the $15 billion loan agreement from December 2015 (as captured via Project ID#95415). The December 2020 agreement included (i) a three-year deferral of principal payments; and (ii) repayment of deferred principal falling due in 2020H2–2023H1 over seven years after the grace period, with some additional modest relief of principal in 2024–25.   The Government of Angola also agreed to use the outstanding cash balance in an escrow account — known as the Debt Service Reserve Account (DSRA) — to make interest payments to the CDB between 2020 to 2022, which it expected would bring the DSRA balance to nearly zero by mid-2022. However, under the terms of the debt reprofiling agreement, the parties agreed that the borrower would need to replenish the DSRA to approximately $1.5 billion (the minimum cash balance previously agreed upon by the lender and borrower) by 2023.
justification: Loan primarily supports Angola's state-owned oil company and is tied to oil revenues, reinforcing fossil fuel dependency
evidence: Oil prepayment facility, proceeds used to recapitalize Sonangol (state oil company), repayments tied to oil receivables

title: China Donated Literacy Materials to the Dos Santos Foundation in Angola (Linked to Project ID #87557, #67722, #68537 and #89351)
description: March 17, 2016, Cui Aimin, Chinese Ambassador to Angola, attended the ceremony to donate literacy materials to the Dos Santos Foundation. The Vice-President of the Foundation, Lombard, Secretary-General, Deus, Director of the Department of Adult Education of the Ministry of Education, Makuru, and UNESCO Representative of the Security Council, Valentin, attended the ceremony. In addition to donated materials, China is ready to exchange experience in the safe side area of ​​literacy, learn from each other and mutual benefit. This is the third consecutive year that tthe Chinese Embassy donated stationery to Dos Santos Literacy Foundation. 3 years, China donated literacy materials distributed by the Dos Santos Foundation to secure the 18 provinces more than 30 schools and NGO agencies benefitting more than 100,000 local people benefit.
staff_comments: Total cost of project is unknown
combined_text:
# Sector
EDUCATION

# Title
China Donated Literacy Materials to the Dos Santos Foundation in Angola (Linked to Project ID #87557, #67722, #68537 and #89351)

# Description
March 17, 2016, Cui Aimin, Chinese Ambassador to Angola, attended the ceremony to donate literacy materials to the Dos Santos Foundation. The Vice-President of the Foundation, Lombard, Secretary-General, Deus, Director of the Department of Adult Education of the Ministry of Education, Makuru, and UNESCO Representative of the Security Council, Valentin, attended the ceremony. In addition to donated materials, China is ready to exchange experience in the safe side area of ​​literacy, learn from each other and mutual benefit. This is the third consecutive year that tthe Chinese Embassy donated stationery to Dos Santos Literacy Foundation. 3 years, China donated literacy materials distributed by the Dos Santos Foundation to secure the 18 provinces more than 30 schools and NGO agencies benefitting more than 100,000 local people benefit.
justification: Project focuses on education and literacy support without direct environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Donation of literacy materials, focus on education and literacy improvement, no energy-related components

title: Haishan Group in China donated Children's Day materials to a primary school in Angola
description: In June 2016, a Chinese construction company donated materials the No. 2059 primary school in southern Luanda, Angola. The materials included toys, rice, instant noodles, cooking oil, mineral waters. Approximately 350 pupils attend the school, most of whom come from impoverished and needy families of the neighboring Belas district. The deputy mayor of Bellas City, Feralas, teachers and students of the school, Zheng Gang, the chairman of the construction company Haishan Group, and other representatives of the company attended the event. The ceremony was meant to celebrate international children's day.
combined_text:
# Sector
EDUCATION

# Title
Haishan Group in China donated Children's Day materials to a primary school in Angola

# Description
In June 2016, a Chinese construction company donated materials the No. 2059 primary school in southern Luanda, Angola. The materials included toys, rice, instant noodles, cooking oil, mineral waters. Approximately 350 pupils attend the school, most of whom come from impoverished and needy families of the neighboring Belas district. The deputy mayor of Bellas City, Feralas, teachers and students of the school, Zheng Gang, the chairman of the construction company Haishan Group, and other representatives of the company attended the event. The ceremony was meant to celebrate international children's day.
justification: Project is a social development initiative focused on education and children's welfare, with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Donation of materials to primary school, focus on children's welfare and education, no energy or industrial components

title: China Donated Materials to Kuzola Orphanage in Angola
description: December 21, 2016, Zhang Zhengxi, Chinese Ambassador to Angola, attended the donation of materials to the KUZOLA Orphanage in Luanda, Angola. Xu Ning, President of the Angolan Chinese Chamber of Commerce, Liu Guiying, President of the Chinese Women's Federation of Angola, and more than 40 representatives of Chinese-funded enterprises and individuals participated.
staff_comments: additional sources could not be found in English and Chinese. Specific funding organization is unknown, and the transaction amount is unknown.
